docs.title: AutomixIQ
docs.text: Enable smooth transitions between tracks for a seamlessly beat-matched experience within your Android music application.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
AutomixIQ is a framework that exposes a music player which analyzes tracks in your application. It offers machine-learned transitions between tracks and when seeking, essentially serving as an automated DJ for your music. The framework determines the ideal points in each song to smoothly transition to the next, synchronizing beats and matching keys.

This documentation provides a step-by-step guide on how to get started with using the AutomixIQ in your application.

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: You can find the documentation of available APIs here: AutomixIQ API Reference

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
As AutomixIQ analyses tracks to generate transitions, it also makes waveform data available to be accessed by the client application for rendering on screen.

Once data is available, the onWaveformDataAvailable method in AutomixSDKStatusListener will be invoked.

See Implement status listener.

docs.title: Setting resolution
docs.text:
The resolution of the waveform data can be set with a maximum of 1024 points (defaults to 256)

val waveformResolution: Int = myWaveformResolution      // default 256, maximum 1024

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.setWaveformPointsPerTrack(waveformResolution)

docs.title: Accessing placeholder data
docs.text:
The placeholder waveform data is accessible whilst AutomixIQ is analysing the track and does not have the waveform data ready.

val placeholderWaveform = AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.placeholderWaveformDataForTrack(trackId)

The above function returns AutomixSDKWaveformModel.

docs.title: Accessing waveform data
docs.text:
The waveform data will be ready once AutomixIQ has finished analysing the track.

val waveform = AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.waveformDataForTrack(trackId, applyEnterTransition = true, applyExitTransition = true)

The above function returns AutomixSDKWaveformModel.

docs.title: Audio file requirements
docs.text:
For efficient mixing with streamed audio, AutomixIQ requires that the audio is stored in a format that supports sample-accurate real-time seeking with only partial file downloads. In practice, this means that formats with a fine-grained seek table are preferred. The only common compressed audio file format that meets these requirements is AAC audio contained in the MPEG-4 file format, typically with mp4 or m4a file extensions.

There are two distinct families of audio formats:

  • Formats with integrated encoding and file structure:

    • Example: mp3 files.
    • These formats do not separate the packets of encoded audio from the file structure.

  • Formats with separated container and audio packets:

    • Example: Ogg/Vorbis.
    • These formats separate the container (e.g., Ogg) from the format of the audio packets (e.g., Vorbis).

Due to this separation, some audio compression standards like AAC may or may not support the above requirements, depending on the container format. ADTS containers, for example, require scanning the entire file to construct a seek table and are not preferred, but they are included to support mislabeled AAC files.

docs.title: With Tuned Global Backend
docs.text:
The high quality audio setting is designed to work with AutomixIQ.

Please make sure the user's audio quality is set to high before loading any tracks into AutomixIQ's player.

docs.title: With custom backend
docs.text:
The default configuration of AutomixIQ supports AAC-LC in MPEG-4 or ADTS containers.

Upon request, AutomixIQ can be configured to support additional file formats. These formats include MP3, Opus, Vorbis, FLAC, and ALAC decoders, as well as Ogg and CAF containers.

docs.title: Configure the SDK with custom backend
Overview
docs.text:
This document explains how to integrate AutomixIQ with your application you are using a custom backend to access tracks and metadata.

To initialise AutomixIQ when you take the responsibility of providing audio data and metadata you need:

  • A store ID and an application ID provided by the Tuned Global team
  • An implementation of the AutomixSDKStreamingListener interface

docs.title: Implement your AutomixSDKStreamingListener
docs.text:
AutomixSDKStreamingListener is an interface that provides AutomixIQ with the essential information from your service to support playback. Extend the AutomixSDKStreamingListener class and implement the required functions as shown below:

  • isLoggedIn
  • asyncCheckDeviceStatus
  • getDeviceIdentifier
  • syncGetTrackMetadata
  • syncGetCachedTrack
  • cacheMetadata
  • asyncGetTrackMetadata
  • asyncGetStream
  • onTrackDownloadCompeleted
  • onTrackDownloadProgressChanged

You can find a detailed explanation in API Reference

public class MyAutomixSDKStreamingListener: AutomixSDKStreamingListener {

    // Return whether the user is logged in
    override fun isLoggedIn() {
        return this.loggedIn
    }

    // Query and inform whether the device is allowed to continue playing by calling onComplete/onError
    override fun asyncCheckDeviceStatus(onComplete: ((Boolean) -> Unit)?,
                                        onError: ((AutomixSDKError) -> Unit)?) -> Unit) {
        this.canDeviceContinuePlaying() { allowedToPlay ->
            onComplete(allowedToPlay)
        }
    }

    // Return this device's unique identifier
    override fun getDeviceIdentifier(): String? {
        return this.deviceIdentifier
    }

    // Return the track metadata if available offline or cached
    override fun syncGetTrackMetadata(trackId: String?): AutomixSDKTrackModel? {
        // If this track is cached, return its metadata
        if (!this.isTrackCached(trackId)) {
            return null
        }
        return this.metadataForTrack(trackId)
    }

    // Return the track data if available offline or cached 
    override fun syncGetCachedTrack(trackId: String): ByteArray? {
        // If this track is cached, return its data
        if (!this.isTrackCached(trackId)) {
            return null
        }
        return this.unencryptedDataForTrack(trackId)
    }

    // Cache this metadata for later use
    override fun cacheMetadata(metadata: List<AutomixSDKTrackModel>) {
        this.metadataForTrack[metadata.trackId] = metadata
    }

    // Download the track metadata and return it to AutomixIQ by running onComplete/onError
    override fun asyncGetTrackMetadata(trackId: String,
                                       onComplete: ((AutomixSDKTrackModel) -> Unit)?,
                                       onError: ((AutomixSDKError) -> Unit)?) -> Unit) {
        this.getTrackMetadata(trackId) { error, trackMetadata ->
            val automixSDKTrackModel = translateMetadata(trackMetadata)
            if (error != null) {
                onError(error)
                return@getTrackMetadata
            }
            onComplete(automixSDKTrackModel)
            return@getTrackMetadata
        }
    }

    // Retrieve the track's url, and return it to AutomixIQ by running onComplete/onError
    override fun asyncGetStream(streamingDeviceId: String, sessionId: String, trackId: String, 
                                onComplete: ((String /* URL */, String? /* newSessionId */) -> Unit)?,
                                onError: ((AutomixSDKError) -> Unit)?) {
        this.getTrackURL(streamingDeviceId, sessionId, trackId) { error, url, newSessionId ->
            if (error != null) {
                onError(error)
                return@getTrackURL
            }
            onComplete(url, newSessionId, null)
        }
    }

    // AutomixIQ will return the audio data once a download is completed
    override fun onTrackDownloadCompeleted(trackId: String, data: ByteArray) {
        this.cacheTrack(trackId, data)
    }

    // Monitor the download progress (0 to 1)
    override fun onTrackDownloadProgressChanged(trackId: String, progress: Float) {
        this.updateTrackDownloadProgress(trackId, progress)
    }
}

Do keep in mind that AutomixIQ downloads tracks lazily as it requires data for analysis / playback. There is no guarantee a track will be fully downloaded if the track is not played in its entirety.

docs.title: Initialise AutomixSDK instance
docs.text:
Create an AutomixSDKConfig first. You can get the store ID, application ID from the Tuned Global team.

val automixConfig = 
    AutomixSDKConfig.Builder()
        .apiKey(myAPIKey)
        .country(myCountryISO2Code) // Device country code e.g. "US", "AU"
        .storeId(myTunedStoreId )
        .applicationId(myTunedApplicationId)
        .logLevel(AutomixSDKLogLevel.DEBUG)
        .build()

Initialise the AutomixSDK instance with the AutomixSDKStreamingListener and AutomixSDKConfig created in previous steps. We recommend initialising the SDK once your music background service is up and running.

Note

AutomixIQ requires an active internet connection for its initial verification. After this initial setup, it can be initialised offline. However, note that there is a grace period of 7 days, after which an internet connection will be required again for re-verification.

    AutomixSDK.initialise(applicationContext,
                          automixSDKStreamingListener,
                          config,
                          onComplete = 
    { _ -> 
        // The Automix SDK public functions can be used from this point onwards :)

        // We can add a status listener to get UI updates and play events
        val automixSDKStatusListener: AutomixSDKStatusListener = myAutomixSDKStatusListener
        AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.addStatusListener(automixSDKStatusListener)

        // ...
    }, onError = { error, _ ->
        // This means you are forbidden to use the Automix SDK or you have no internet connection.
    })

docs.title: Configure the SDK with Tuned Global backend
Overview
docs.text:
This document explains how to integrate AutomixIQ with your application if it is already using Tuned Global’s backend to access tracks and metadata.

To initialise AutomixIQ with Tuned Global's API and services, you need

  • A store ID and an application ID provided by the Tuned Global team
  • An implementation of the TunedRestHook interface

docs.title: Implement your TunedRestHook
docs.text:
TunedRestHook is an interface that facilitates communication between the Tuned Global Backend and the AutomixIQ SDK regarding the user's access token and device information. Extend the TunedRestHook class and implement the required functions as shown below:

  • getAuthenticatedDevice
  • getUniqueDeviceIdentifier
  • onTunedRestTokenExpired

You can find a detailed explanation in API Reference

class MyTunedRestHook: TunedRestHook {

    // Return the Tuned API device ID integer
    override suspend fun getAuthenticatedDevice(uniqueDeviceIdentifier: String): String? {
        val myTunedDeviceId: String = tunedDeviceId
        return myTunedDeviceId
    }

    // Return an ID that can be used to identify a device.
    // This is typically a randomly generated UUID that persists through app restarts.
    override fun getUniqueDeviceIdentifier(): String {
        val uuid: String = myUniqueDeviceIdentifier
        return uuid
    }

    // Use the info provided from the parameters to refresh the Tuned user token
    override suspend fun onTunedRestTokenExpired(uniqueDeviceIdentifier: String,
                                                 countryCode: String,
                                                 tunedUserId: String?,
                                                 oldAccessToken: String?,
                                                 refreshToken: String?,
                                                 tokenType: String?): TunedAuthenticationResponse? {
        // your implementation of refreshing Tuned user token
        val tunedAuthenticationResponse: TunedAuthenticationResponse? = null
        withContext(Dispatchers.IO) {
            suspendCancellableCoroutine { continuation ->
                refreshToken(refreshToken, tokenType, uniqueDeviceIdentifier) { authToken, tokenType, tokenExpiration, refreshToken ->
                    val userId = tunedUserId
                    tunedAuthenticationResponse = TunedAuthenticationResponse(authToken,
                                                                              tokenType,
                                                                              tokenExpiration,
                                                                              refreshToken,
                                                                              tunedUserId)
                    continuation.resume(Unit)
                }
            }
        }
        return tunedAuthenticationResponse
    }
}

docs.text:
Create an AutomixSDKConfig first. The store and application ID will be provided by the Tuned Global team.

val automixConfig = 
    AutomixSDKConfig.Builder()
        .apiKey(myAPIKey)
        .country(myCountryISO2Code) // Device country code e.g. "US", "AU"

Note

AutomixIQ requires an active internet connection for its initial verification. After this initial setup, it can be initialised offline. However, note that there is a grace period of 7 days, after which an internet connection will be required again for re-verification.

    AutomixSDK.initialise(applicationContext,
                      myTunedRestHook,
                      automixConfig,
                      onComplete = { automixStatus ->

        // The AutomixIQ public functions can be used from this point onwards :)

        return

docs.title: Implement TunedMusicCacheHook (Optional)
docs.text:
AutomixIQ supports offline playback using local music data. You can implement the TunedMusicCacheHook to

  • provide track metadata and cached audio data,
  • extract audio data downloaded by AutomixIQ
  • monitor the download progress

This approach enhances efficiency and prevents AutomixIQ from having to request this data from Tuned Global’s API if they are already available. This also enables offline playback when all the required data is available locally.

Implement the TunedMusicCacheHook and add it to the SDK after initialisation. You can find a detailed explanation in API Reference

SetMusicCacheHook
AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.setMusicCacheHook(MyMusicCacheHook())
MyMusicCacheHook
public class MyMusicCacheHook: TunedMusicCacheHook {

    // Provide the track metadata. For offline playback, this is required if the metadata is not loaded when playing tracks.
    override fun getTrackMetadata(trackId: String?): AutomixSDKTrackModel? {
        // If the track is not cached, return null and AutomixIQ will try to fetch it.
        if (!isTrackCached(trackId)) {
            return null
        }
        return metadataForTrack(trackId)
    }

    // Provide the cached audio data. For offline playback, this is required.
    override fun getCachedTrack(trackId: String): ByteArray? {
        // If the track is not cached, return null and AutomixIQ will try to stream it.
        if (!isTrackCached(trackId)) {
            return null
        }

        return rawAudioDataForTrack(trackId)
    }

    // AutomixIQ will 
    // - stream and download the tracks when they are not provided from `getCachedTrack` and call this method once the download for each track has completed
    // - use the cached audio data from getCachedTrack and call this method once the data provided is verified for each track
    override fun onTrackDownloadCompeleted(trackId: String, data: ByteArray) {
        cacheTrack(trackId, data)
    }

    // Monitor the download progress (0 to 1)
    override fun onTrackDownloadProgressChanged(trackId: String, progress: Float) {
        updateTrackBufferingProgress(trackId, progress)
    }
}

Note

If the byte data for a track provided through getCachedTrack does not fit the Audio file requirements. AutomixIQ will try to stream the track from the connected backend.

docs.title: Control playback
docs.text:
AutomixIQ's player needs to be turned on before using any of the following playback controls API, see Turn AutomixIQ on and off.

Use the AutomixSDK instance to control playback.

AutomixSDK.getInstance()

Playback control APIs include:

  • Load tracks
  • Add track
  • Add tracks
  • Remove track
  • Move track
  • Reorder tracks (Shuffle)
  • Clear playlist
  • Play
  • Pause
  • Next
  • Previous
  • Skip to a track
  • Back
  • Seek
  • Loop track
  • Stop looping track
  • Force pause after playback of current track

docs.title: Load tracks
docs.text:
Loads a new set of tracks into the AutomixIQ player, it will override the currently loaded playlist.

Note

Please make sure you adhere to the Audio file requirements before loading any tracks to AutomixIQ

val identifiers: List<String> = myPlaylist 
val metadataList: List<AutomixSDKTrackModel> = mySetOfMetadata
val index = myPlaylistIndex
val startPositionSeconds = myTrackStartPosition
val contextType: String = myContextType
val contextId: String = myContextId

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.loadTracks(
    identifiers = identifiers,
    metadata = metadataList,
    playTrackIndex = index.coerceAtLeast(0),
    seconds = startPositionSeconds,
    autoplay = true,
    contextType = contextType,      // for reporting purposes
    contextId = contextId,          // for reporting purposes
    onComplete = { automixSDKStatus ->
        // Success
    },
    onError = { automixSDKError, automixSDKStatus ->
        // Error
    }
)

docs.title: Data persistency
docs.text: AutomixIQ keeps minimal local files to ensure the SDK runs smoothly.

docs.title: Music Metadata Database
docs.text: In the cache directory dedicated to your app, AutomixIQ maintains a lightweight SQL database music.db to store the metadata of tracks that have been played for subsequent lookup. This file is automatically created on launch if it does not exist.

docs.title: Music Analysis Database
docs.text: In the cache directory dedicated to your app, AutomixIQ keeps a lightweight SQL database paralysis.db to store the analysis data of tracks that have been played. This analysis data is essential to produce beat-matched transitions. This file is automatically created on launch if it does not exist.

docs.title: Transition Playback Log
docs.text: AutomixIQ stores offline transition playback logs for reporting purposes in a SQLite database.

docs.title: Clear cache
docs.text:
To reset persistent analysis storage

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.clearCache()

docs.title: Explicit lyrics filter
docs.text: AutomixIQ can be set to exclude tracks with explicit content. It will automatically skip or transition out of these tracks during playback.

docs.title: Check if a track is explicit
docs.text:
An explicit track is identified by the isExplicit flag in its AutomixSDKTrackModel.

You can mark a track as explicit by setting the isExplicit flag when providing metadata to AutomixIQ.

docs.title: Turn on/off explicit filter
docs.text:
val filterExplicit: Boolean = true      // or false

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.setFilterExplicit(filterExplicit,
    onComplete = { automixSDKStatus ->
        // Success
    },
    onError = { automixSDKError, automixSDKStatus ->
        // Error
    }
)

docs.title: After turning on explicit filter
docs.text:
• If this filtering is enabled when the current track is not explicit, then AutomixIQ will ensure the mix skips over tracks with explicit content by creating a mix between the current track and the first non-explicit track. If no non-explicit track is available, then AutomixIQ will act as if that track is the end of the playlist. If replay is on, then it will look from the beginning of the playlist to find the next non-explicit track.

  • If this filtering is enabled when the current track is explicit, then AutomixIQ will automatically skip to the first available non-explicit track. If no non-explicit track is available, then AutomixIQ will act as if that track is the end of the playlist. If replay is on, then it will look from the beginning of the playlist to find the next non-explicit track.

docs.title: Handle error
docs.text:
Most of the public APIs of AutomixIQ will return an AutomixSDKError object through the onError method if any error is encountered.

You can find a detailed list of errors here: AutomixSDKError Reference.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text: This SDK requires a minimum of Android API Level 21.

docs.title: Importing artifacts
docs.text:
AutomixIQ can be brought into your project via our private maven repository.

Step 1: Include Tuned Global's maven repository

settings.gradle.kts
dependencyResolutionManagement {
     repositoriesMode.set(RepositoriesMode.FAIL_ON_PROJECT_REPOS)
     repositories {
         // ...
         maven(url = "https://tunedglobal.pkgs.visualstudio.com/TunedAutomix.Android.Releases/_packaging/AutoMixAndroidFeed/maven/v1")
         // ...
     }
}

Step 2: Add the dependency to your target

build.gradle.kts
// Please check Tuned Global's maven repository for the latest available version
val automixIQVersion = myAutomixIQVersion // 0.5.0

dependencies {
    // ...
    implementation("com.tunedglobal:automixiq:$automixIQVersion")
    // ...
}

Step 3: You should now be able to use AutomixIQ

import com.tunedglobal.automix.*

-keep class com.tunedglobal.automix.logic.cpp.AMJNILib {

}

docs.title: Player setting
docs.text:
AutomixIQ's player provides a list of settings for enhanced control over playback.

Use the AutomixSDK instance to modify player settings.

AutomixSDK.getInstance()

Player setting APIs include:

  • Playback speed
  • Mute
  • Replay
  • Vinyl start/stop SFX
  • Volume
  • Transition duration
  • Explicit filter

docs.title: Playback speed
docs.text:
Adjust the playback speed with a wider range. The accepted range is 0.5x to 2x of the original playback speed.

  • Setting the value to 0.5 will play the track at 0.5x speed
  • Setting the value to 1 will play the track at 1x speed
  • Setting the value to 2 will play the track at 2x speed
  • You can set the value anywhere between 0.5 and 2
val playbackSpeed: Float = myPlaybackSpeed      // range from 0.5 to 2

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.setAutomixPlaySpeed(playbackSpeed,
    onComplete = { automixSDKStatus ->
        // Success
    },
    onError = { automixSDKError, automixSDKStatus ->
        // Error
    }
)

docs.title: Volume
docs.text:
Adjust the volume of the player. This does not change the Android system volume.

val volumeNormalised: Float = myVolumeNormalised    // range from 0 to 1

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.setAutomixVolumeNormalised(volumeNormalised,
    onComplete = { automixSDKStatus ->
        // Success
    },
    onError = { automixSDKError, automixSDKStatus ->
        // Error
    }
)

docs.title: Vinyl start/stop SFX
docs.text:
The player plays a vinyl start/stop sound effect when resuming or pausing. Use this API to enable/disable this SFX.

Note

This SFX is turned on by default

val enableVinylSFX: Boolean = true      // or false

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.setVinylStartStopEnabled(enableVinylSFX,
    onComplete = { automixSDKStatus ->

docs.title: Transition duration
docs.text:
Set a preferred transition duration in seconds for the transition between tracks. The SDK will try to generate a smooth transition based on the value set.

// range from 0 to 30. If set as 0, the SDK will decide the best transtion duration
val transitionDurationHint: Float = myTransitionDuration        

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.setPreferredTransitionDurationSeconds(transitionDurationHint,
    onComplete = { status ->
        // Success
    },
    onError = { automixSDKError, status ->
        // Error
    }
)

docs.title: Explicit filter
docs.text: AutomixIQ can be set to exclude tracks with explicit content. It will automatically skip or transition out of these tracks during playback. See Explicit lyrics filter

docs.title: Turn AutomixIQ on and off
docs.text:
AutomixIQ's player can be turned on or off after initialisation. You need to turn on the player before playing any music.

Note

If there is another player currently playing music, we suggest pausing the playback once AutomixIQ's player is turned on to prevent competing for audio control. When AutomixIQ's player is turned off, any other player can be resumed.

docs.title: Turn AutomixIQ on
docs.text:
You can turn on the player without any tracks, or turn on the player with a list of tracks and its metadata.

Note

If you start the player without tracks, tracks will need to be provided via the playback control methods later, see Load tracks.

Turn on without tracks
AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.automixOn(
    onComplete = { automixSDKStatus -> 
        // Player is turned on and is waiting for tracks to be loaded.
    }, onError = { automixSDKError, automixSDKStatus ->
        // Something went wrong, playback did not start
    }
)

Note

Please make sure you adhere to the Audio file requirements before loading any tracks to AutomixIQ

Turn on with tracks
// list of track ids
val electronicMusicPlaylist = listOf("116484855","66906273","120584575","116887896")

// list of `AutomixSDKTrackModel` for tracks
val cachedMetadata = listOf(trackMetadata1, trackMetadata2, trackMetadata3, trackMetadata4) 

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.automixOn(
    identifiers = electronicMusicPlaylist,
    metadata = cachedMetadata,      // nullable, if null and the SDK will call `getTrackMetadata` in `TunedMusicCacheHook` to get metadata
    playTrackIndex = 0,             // start playback index in playlist
    seconds = 0,                    // start playback seconds in track
    autoplay = true,                // start playback immediately or not
    contextType = "playlist",       // for reporting purposes
    contextId = "playlist-id",      // for reporting purposes
    onComplete = { automixSDKStatus -> 
        // Player is turned on and will start playback if autoplay is true
    }, onError = { automixSDKError, automixSDKStatus ->
        // Something went wrong, playback did not start
    }
)

docs.title: Turn AutomixIQ off
docs.text:
Turning off AutomixIQ's player will stop playback

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.automixOff(
    onComplete = { automixSDKStatus -> 
        // Playback should be stopped by now, resume other players if needed.
        // `automixSDKStatus` contains the last status of the player, can be used to provide information to other players to resume playback.
    },
    onError = { automixSDKError, automixSDKStatus ->
        // Something went wrong, playback did not stop
    }
)

For more information about AutomixSDKStatus, see Update UI.

docs.title: Check on/off state
docs.text:
To check whether AutomixIQ's player is turned on

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.on()

docs.title: Update UI
docs.text: AutomixIQ provides realtime status update and playback events after the player starts playing. You can register multiple listeners to monitor the status of the player and update your UI accordingly.

docs.title: Register status listener
docs.text:
You can register a status listener any time after the SDK is initialised.

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.addStatusListener(myStatusListener)

docs.title: Unregister status listener
docs.text:
You can unregister the listener and stop receiving status updates and events when you do not need it any more.

AutomixSDK.getInstance()?.removeStatusListener(myStatusListener)

docs.title: Implement status listener
docs.text:
Extend the AutomixSDKStatusListener class and implement the required functions as shown below:

  • onStatusChanged
  • onPlaybackEvent
  • onWaveformDataAvailable
class MyStatusListener: AutomixSDKStatusListener {

    override fun onStatusChanged(variables: List<AutomixSDKStatusVariable>, status: AutomixSDKStatus) {
        // Monitor status update
    }

    override fun onPlaybackEvent(type: AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType,
                                 identifier: String?, 
                                 originalSessionId: String?, 
                                 status: AutomixSDKStatus?) {
        // Monitor playback event
    }

    override fun onWaveformDataAvailable(identifier: String) {
        // Monitor waveform data availability
    }
}

docs.title: Monitor status update
docs.text:
AutomixIQ reports the player status every time it is updated. You can get the current player status from the AutomixSDKStatus object and the list of AutomixSDKStatusVariable that gets updated since the last time a onStatusChanged is invoked. Use the value of each AutomixSDKStatusVariable to update your player UI.

For details of each status field, see AutomixSDKStatus and AutomixSDKStatusVariable

var latestStatus: AutomixSDKStatus? = null

override fun onStatusChanged(variables: List<AutomixSDKStatusVariable>, status: AutomixSDKStatus) {
    // Monitor status update

    this.latestStatus = status

    for (property in variables) {    
        when (property) {
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.PLAYING -> {
                // Change the look and feel of your Play/Pause button here
                val playing = status.playing
                // ...
            }
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.MIXING -> {}
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.PLAYING_TRACK_IDENTIFIER -> {}
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.PLAYING_TRACK_INDEX -> {}
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.PLAYING_TRACK_CURRENT_TIME -> {
                // Change your track progress UI here 
                val elapsedTime = status.playingTrackCurrentTime
                val totalTime = status.playingTrackTotalTime
                // ...
            }
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.PLAYING_TRACK_STREAMING_PROGRESS -> {}
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.PLAYING_TRACK_TOTAL_TIME -> {
                // Change your track progress UI here 
                val elapsedTime = status.playingTrackCurrentTime
                val totalTime = status.playingTrackTotalTime
                // ...
            }
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.CAN_SKIP_TO_PREVIOUS -> {
                // Change the look and feel of your previous button here
                val canSkipToPrevious = status.canSkipToPrevious
                // ...
            }
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.CAN_SKIP_TO_NEXT -> {
                // Change the look and feel of your next button here
                val canSkipToNext = status.canSkipToNext
                // ...
            }
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.CAN_PLAY_PAUSE -> {
                // Change the look and feel of your play/pause button here
                val canPlayPause = status.canPlayPause
                // ...
            }
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.CAN_SEEK -> {}
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.CAN_REORDER_TRACKS -> {}
            AutomixSDKStatusVariable.REPLAY_ON -> {
                // Change the look and feel of your replay button here
                val replayOn = status.replayOn
                // ...
            }

            // ...
            // More `AutomixSDKStatusVariable` enums can be found in API reference
        }
    }
}

A helper function have been created to help you easily get the value of specific AutomixSDKStatusVariable from AutomixSDKStatus

Get value for AutomixSDKStatusVariable
AutomixSDKStatus.getValue<T>(AutomixSDKStatusVariable)

docs.title: Monitor playback event
docs.text:
Certain predefined playback events will be returned during playback to help with reporting.

For details of each playback event, see AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType

override fun onPlaybackEvent(type: AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType,
                             identifier: String?, 
                             originalSessionId: String?, 
                             status: AutomixSDKStatus?) {
    // Monitor playback event
    when (type) {
        AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType.TRACK_PLAY_START -> {}
        AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType.TRACK_PLAY_PLAYED_5_SECS -> {}
        AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType.TRACK_PLAY_HEARTBEAT_30_SECS -> {}
        AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType.TRACK_PLAY_START_MIXING_INTO_NEXT -> {}
        AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType.TRACK_PLAY_SKIPPED -> {}
        AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType.TRACK_PLAY_FINISHED -> {}
        AutomixSDKPlaybackEventType.MIX_PLAYBACK_ENDED -> {}
    }
}

docs.title: Monitor waveform data
docs.text: When the waveform data for a track is ready, AutomixIQ will invoke onWaveformDataAvailable. See Access waveform data.
